author: Ramona Giwargis rgiwargis@mercurynews.com
title: San Jose moving forward with large-scale ethics probe into city's campaign disclosure law
text:
San Jose moving forward with large-scale ethics probe into city's campaign disclosure law By Ramona Giwargis rgiwargis@mercurynews.com Posted: 10/14/2015 07:35:29 PM PDT Updated: 10/14/2015 07:51:38 PM PDT SAN JOSE -- The investigation into nearly 40 candidates seeking public office the last two years -- including Mayor Sam Liccardo and most current City Council members -- should be completed by November, according to a report presented at the city's Ethics Commission meeting Wednesday. 
The commission, a five-member panel tasked with enforcing city election laws and investigating complaints, last month directed an outside law firm to look into what appeared to be widespread violations of San Jose's campaign disclosure law. The law required candidates to report "late contributions" of $250 or more received the last 16 days before an election. 
But only one candidate in the last two years, former District 5 Councilman Xavier Campos, managed to follow the law, which was adopted in 2011. The problem came to light after a citizen filed a complaint against Councilman Manh Nguyen, who contended that nearly all other candidates flouted the city rule. Nguyen was slapped with a $10,000 fine by the commission, while others walked away scot-free because the panel can only investigate when a complaint is filed. 
Within months, someone submitted a complaint against Nguyen's opponent in the District 4 special election, Tim Orozco. To stop people from filing individual complaints against each of the dozens of violators -- prompting countless investigations and penalties -- the commission initiated the unprecedented broad probe. Commissioners won't act on the Orozco complaint until the bigger investigation is done. Advertisement 
Steven Miller, an attorney with Hanson Bridgett, the San Francisco law firm contracted to investigate, said in a letter Wednesday the firm has made contact with candidates included in the investigation. But depending on how quickly they respond or their willingness to be interviewed, Miller wrote, delays could be expected. The firm is pushing to complete the report by the commission's next meeting, tentatively set for Nov. 12. 
The cost of the unique broad investigation -- footed by San Jose taxpayers -- is weighing on some commissioners' minds. Hanson Bridgett gets paid $415 per hour if a partner works on the investigation; $360 if it's senior counsel; $315 for an associate; and $185 for a political compliance specialist. The contract, which expires June 2016, caps the firm's total compensation at $250,000. 
Chairman Michael Smith, who requested a 30-day extension for the attorneys to complete their work, said the firm is aware the commission doesn't want to "break the bank" and has taken steps to control costs. 
"The one difference between this one and the others," said Smith, "is a large part of the labor is stuff that's done by a non-attorney. So that will keep the costs down." Follow Ramona Giwargis at Twitter.com/ramonagiwargis or contact her at 408-920-5705.
